titleStmt.title: Theses Martinianae that is, certaine demonstratiue conclusions, sette downe and collected (as it should seeme) by that famous and renowmed clarke, the reuerend Martin Marprelate the great: seruing as a manifest and sufficient confutation of al that euer the Colledge of Catercaps with their whole band of clergie-priests, haue, or canbring [sic] for the defence of their ambitious and antichristian prelacie. Published and set foorthe as an after-birth of the noble gentleman himselfe, by a prety stripling of his, Martin Iunior, and dedicated by him to his good neame and nuncka, Maister Iohn Kankerbury: hovv the yongman [sic] came by them, the reader shall vunderstande sufficiently in the epilogue. In the meane time, vvhosoeuer can bring mee acquainted vvith my father, Ile bee bounde hee shall not loose his labour.
titleStmt.author: Marprelate, Martin, pseud.

fileDesc.extent: Approx. 49 KB of XML-encoded text transcribed from 16 1-bit group-IV TIFF page images.

titleStmt.title: Theses Martinianae that is, certaine demonstratiue conclusions, sette downe and collected (as it should seeme) by that famous and renowmed clarke, the reuerend Martin Marprelate the great: seruing as a manifest and sufficient confutation of al that euer the Colledge of Catercaps with their whole band of clergie-priests, haue, or canbring [sic] for the defence of their ambitious and antichristian prelacie. Published and set foorthe as an after-birth of the noble gentleman himselfe, by a prety stripling of his, Martin Iunior, and dedicated by him to his good neame and nuncka, Maister Iohn Kankerbury: hovv the yongman [sic] came by them, the reader shall vunderstande sufficiently in the epilogue. In the meane time, vvhosoeuer can bring mee acquainted vvith my father, Ile bee bounde hee shall not loose his labour.
titleStmt.author: Marprelate, Martin, pseud.
Throckmorton, Job, 1545-1601, attributed name.
Penry, John, 1559-1593, attributed name.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed [by John Hodgkins] by the assignes of Martin Iunior, without any priuiledge of the Catercaps,

notesStmt.note: Martin Junior = Martin Marprelate, who has been identified with John Penry and, more probably, with Job Throckmorton.
Place of publication and printer's name from STC. Dated at end: Iuly 22. 1589.
Reproduction of the original in the Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THESIS MARTINIANAE: That is, CERTAINE DEMONSTRATIVE Conclu≈øions, ≈øette downe and collected (as it ≈øhould ≈øeeme) by that famous and renowmed Clarke, the reuerend Martin Marprelate the great: ≈øeruing as a manife≈øt and ≈øufficient confutation of al that euer the Colledge of Catercaps with their whole band of Clergie-prie≈øts, haue, or can bring for the defence of their ambitious and Antichri≈øtian Prelacie.

PVBLISHED AND SET FOORTH as an after-birth of the noble Gentleman him≈øelfe, by a prety ≈øtripling of his, MARTIN IVNIOR, and dedicated by him to his good neame and nuncka, Mai≈øter Iohn Kankerbury: Hovv the yong man came by them, the Reader shall vnder≈øtande ≈øufficiently in the Epilogue, In the meane time, vvho≈øoeuer can bring mee acquainted vvith my father, Ile bee bounde hee shall not loo≈øe his labour.
Printed by the a≈øsignes of Martin Iunior, without any priuiledge of the Catercaps.

div.head: Martin Iunior ≈øonne vnto the renowmed and worthy Martin Marprelate the Great, to the Reader.
div.p: THou ≈øhalt receiue (good Reader) before I ≈øet downe vnto thee anie thing of mine owne, certeyne of tho≈øe thinges of my fathers dooings which I found among his vnperfect papers: I haue not changed any thing in them, detracted any thing from them, nor added vnto them aught of mine owne, but as I found them, ≈øo I haue deliuered them vnto thee. Mine owne meaning thou ≈øhalt vnder≈øtand at the latter ende in my Epilogue, to my nunckle Canturburie. This ≈ømall thing that followeth before his The≈øes, is al≈øo his owne. I haue ≈øet downe the ≈øpeach as I founde it, though vnperfect. One thing I am ≈øory for, that the ≈øpeach pretendeth the old man to be ≈øomething di≈øcouraged in his cour≈øes.

div.head: THESES MARTINIANAE.
div.p:
I See my doings and my cour≈øe mi≈øliked of many both the good and the bad, though al≈øo I haue fauourers of both ≈øortes. The Bi≈øhops, and their traine, though they ≈øtumble at the cau≈øe, yet e≈øpecially, mi≈ølike my maner of writing. Tho≈øe whom fooli≈øhly men call Puritanes, like of the matter I haue handled, but the forme they cannot brooke. So that herein I haue them both for mine aduer≈øaries. But nowe what if I ≈øhould take the cour≈øe „Äà1 span left blank„Äâ in certeine The≈øes or conclu≈øions, without inueighing again≈øt either per≈øon or cau≈øe? might I not then hope my doings woulde be altogether approoued of the one, and not ≈øo greatly ≈øcorned at by the other? Surely, otherwi≈øe they ≈øhould doe me great iniurie, and ≈øhewe, that they are tho≈øe who delight neither in heate nor colde, and ≈øo make me as weary in ≈øeeking howe to fitte them as the Bi≈øhops are in labouring how to find me. The Bi≈øhops I feare are pa≈øt my cure, and it may be I was vnwi≈øe, in taking that charge vpon me: if that which I haue already done can do them any good, or any wi≈øe further the cau≈øe which I loue, I ≈øhall be glad, if not, what hope is there of amending them this way? The be≈øt is I know how to mend my ≈øelfe. For good leaue haue I to giue ouer my de≈øparate cure, and with this my farewell vnto them, I wi≈øh them a better Surgeon. Yet ere I leaue them, I do heere offer vnto the view of the world, ≈øome part of their mon≈øtrous corruptions; in defence whereof, for their liues dare not they in any learned meeting or a≈ø≈øembly di≈øpute with with me, or attempt to ouerthrowe mine a≈ø≈øertions by mode≈øt writings handled any thing ≈øcholerlike,
that is, by good and ≈øounde ≈øyllogi≈ømes, which haue both their Maior and Minor, confirmed by the worde. I woulde once ≈øee them enter into either of the≈øe cour≈øes, for as yet they haue beene farre from both. Fire, and fagot, bands, and blowes, railing, and reuiling, are, and haue bene hitherto their common weapons, as for ≈ølandering & lying, it is the greate≈øt piece of their holy profe≈ø≈øion. And the≈øe with their bare a≈ø≈øertioÃÑs, & their wretched cleuing to popi≈øh ab≈øurdities, are in a maner the onely proofes and tried maximes they offer vnto the Church in this age. And ≈øo if a man woulde be confuted, I mu≈øt needes ≈øay, my Lord of Winche≈øter hath long agoe ≈øufficiently and dexterely performed it. I am not of opinion, (≈øaith he) that, vna ≈øemper debet e≈ø≈øe oeconomia Eccle≈øiae, That the gouernement of the Church ≈øhoulde alwayes, and in all places, bee one and the ≈øame, e≈øpecially by a company of Elders. Lo ≈øir, what ≈øay you to this? here is inough, I trowe, for any mans ≈øatisfaction, that bi≈øhop Couper is not of opinion. Yea but our Sauior Chri≈øt his Apo≈øtles & holy Martirs are of opinion, that the gouernment of the church ≈øhould alwayes, and in all places, be one, e≈øpecially by a company of Elders. As for my Lord of Winche≈øters opinion, wee haue little or nothing to doe with that: nor no great matter which ≈øide it leane to, whether with or again≈øt the trueth. For if his bi≈øhopricke and vnruly iuri≈ødiction were no more noy≈øome and hurtfull to the Church of God, then his learning and opinion is hurtfull to the cau≈øe of Di≈øcipline, he might ≈øitte long enough vndi≈øtempered in his chaire for vs: the good olde manne might cough his fill, and be quiet, hauing his faithfull
promi≈øe and booke-oth (as we haue al≈øo Iohn a Bridges and Bancrofts) that by arguments hee will neuer hurt vs. For they mu≈øt thinke, that it is not ≈øuch drie blowes as this, I am not of opinion, &c. that will ≈øatisfie the learned, and an≈øweare the demon≈øtrations that are brought on the contrarie ≈øide. If then they haue indeede any purpo≈øe at all, to quiet the contentions of our Church, let them bring vnto vs, not the≈øe bables of their owne, VVe are not of opinion, &c. but ≈øome ≈øound warrant from the word, that Chri≈øt and his Apo≈øtles vvere not of opinion with vs in the pointes wherein wee truelie charge them to haue erred, otherwi≈øe their 812. their 1401.

div.head: THESES MARTINIANAE: That is, The vnan≈øwerable Conclu≈øions of MARTIN, wherein are plainely ≈øet downe many ≈øtraunge and vnknowen things (if hereafter they may be prooued) again≈øt the Bi≈øhops.
div.byline: Compiled by Martin the Great: found and publi≈øhed by Martin Iunior, for the benefite of po≈øteritie, if his fathers ≈øhould be ≈ølaine.
div.p: 1 THat al the officers of a true & lawful church gouernement in regarde of their offices, are members of the vi≈øible bodie of Chri≈øt, which is the Church. Rom. 12.4,5. &c. 1. Cor. 12.8,28.
2 That none but Chri≈øt alone is to ordeine the members of his bodie, to wit, of the Church: Becau≈øe

3 That the Lorde in his worde hath left the church perfect in all her members, which he ≈øhold nor haue done, if he had not ordeined all the officers, namely, the members thereof, and ≈øo hee ≈øhould leaue the building of his church vnperfect, and ≈øo it mu≈øt continue, for who wil pre≈øume to fini≈øh that which hee hath left vndone in the building of his Church.

4 That to ordeine a perfect and an vnchangeable gouernement of the Church, is, a part of Chri≈øtes prerogatiue royall, and therfore cannot, without the great derogation of the Sonne of God; bee claimed by any Church or man.

5 That if Chri≈øt did not ordeine a Church-gouernement, which at the plea≈øure of man can not be changed, then hee is inferiour vnto Mo≈øes, for the gouernment placed by him might no man to alter, and thereto might no man adde any thing. Heb. 3.2,3.
6 That the Lorde in the Newe Te≈øtament did appoint as perfite and vnchangeable a forme of Church-gouernement in the offices and officets thereof, as Mo≈øes did in the olde.
7 That the Lorde neuer placed any offices in the Newe Te≈øtament, but the offices of Apo≈øtles, Prophets, Euangeli≈øtes, Pa≈øtors, Doctours, Elders, and Deacons.
8 That vnto the end of the worlde there were no other offices to bee placed in the Church, but onely the≈øe.

9 That none of the≈øe were, and ≈øo no offices of a lawful Church-gouernement are to be remoued out of the Church, by any but by the Lorde Chri≈øt
him≈øelfe, who placed them, becau≈øe they are the members of his body, in the placing or di≈øplacing whereof, man hath no skill, nor yet commi≈ø≈øion to deale.

10 That the Lord for the cau≈øes ≈øeeming good to his owne wi≈øedome (whereof any further then hee hath ≈øet downe in his worde man is not to enquire) hath remoued out of the church the offices of Apo≈øtles, Prophets, and Euangeli≈øts.
11 That the want of the≈øe can bee no maime vnto the church, ≈øeeing the Lorde by remoouing them thence, ≈øheweth, that the body can haue no v≈øe of them.
12 That the church is nowe vnto the worldes end, to haue none other offices in it, but of pa≈øtors, doctors, elders, and deacons.
13 That the di≈øplacing, or the want of the≈øe, is a maime vnto the church: And therefore.
14 That the churches of God in Denmarke, Saxony, Tygurium, &c. wanting this gouernment by the≈øe offices, are to be accompted maimed and vnperfect.

15 That it is as good a rea≈øon, yea, and a farre better, to ≈øay, that learned men, and valiant captaines, mu≈øt haue their eyes put out, becau≈øe Homer and Zi≈øca were blinde, as to auouch that the church of England may not bee gouerned by Pa≈øtors, Doctors, Elders, and deacons, becau≈øe other good churches want this regiment.
16 That to place others in the ≈øteade of the≈øe, is both a maiming and a deforming of the church.
17 That no magi≈øtrate may lawfully maime or deforme the body of Chri≈øt, which is the Church: And therefore.
18 That no lawefull Church-gouernement is changeable at the plea≈øure of the magi≈øtrate.

19 That the platforme of gouernement by Pa≈øtors, Doctors, Elders, and Deacons, was not deui≈øed by man, but by our Sauiour Chri≈øt him≈øelfe, the onely head, and alone vniuer≈øall Bi≈øhop of his church, as it is ≈øet downe Rom. 12.4,5. Ephe≈ø. 4.12. and 1. Cor. 12.8,28. God hath ordained, ≈øaith the Apo≈øtle.
20 That no inconuenience can po≈ø≈øibly come vnto anie ≈øtate, by receiuing this gouernement.
21 That the true ≈øtabilitie of al chri≈øtian ≈øtates and common-wealths con≈øi≈øteth in the ≈øound execution of this church-gouernement, by Pa≈øtors, Doctors, Elders, and Deacons.
22 That of nece≈ø≈øitie all chri≈øtian Magi≈øtrates are bound to receiue this gouernment by Pa≈øtors, Doctors, Elders, and Deacons, and to aboli≈øh al other church-gouernements.
23 That a church gouernement, being the ordinaunce of the magi≈øtrate, or of the church, is an vnlawfull church-gouernement.

24 That it is meerely and vtterly vnlawfull for anie man, church, or ≈øtate, to ordeine anie church-gouernement, or anie church officer, ≈øaue that gouernement, and tho≈øe officers before named: Becau≈øe.
25 That a church-gouernement con≈øi≈øting of any other officers, but Pa≈øtors, Doctors, Elders, & Deacons, is a gouernment of maimed and mi≈øhapen members: Therefore

26 That our church-gouernement in England by lord archbi≈øhops, and bi≈øhops, is a gouernment of maimed, vnnaturall, and deformed members,
≈øeruing for no v≈øe in the church of God: Therefore al≈øo
27 That no lord bi≈øhop is to be maintained in anie chri≈øtian common wealth.

28 That tho≈øe kingdomes and ≈øtates, who defend any church-gouernement, ≈øaue this of Pa≈øtors, Doctors, Elders, and Deacons, are in danger of vtter de≈øtruction, in as much as they defend the maime and deformitie of the church: And therefore

29 That our lord archbi≈øhops and bi≈øhops, in defending this their vngodly gouernment, are, not onelie traitours to God and his church, but vtter enemies vnto her Maie≈øtie, and the State, in as much as they enforce the Lord by the≈øe their ≈øins, to drawe the ≈øworde again≈øt vs to our vtter ruine.
30 That our lord archbi≈øhops & bi≈øhops holde it lawfull for our magi≈øtrates to maime or deforme the church.
31 That they holde Ie≈øus Chri≈øt to haue left behinde him, an vnperfite and a maimed church, wanting ≈øome of her members.
32 That they holde it lawful for the magi≈øtrate to aboli≈øh the true and naturall members of the body, and to attempt the making of newe by his owne inuention.
33 That they, to wit, archbi≈øhops and bi≈øhops, are the maime of our church, and like to bee the de≈øtruction of our common-wealth.

34 That the warrant that the archbi≈øhops and bi≈øhops haue for their places, can be no better then the warrant which the maintenaunce of the open and mo≈øt mon≈øtrous whoredome in the Stewes had in times pa≈øt amonge≈øt vs. For by the worde
they are condemned to be the maime or deformitie of the church, or both. And as for the laws that maintaine them, being the wound and ≈øore of the church, they are no more to be accounted of, then the lawes mainteining the Stewes.
35 That the places of lord bi≈øhops are neither warranted by the word of God, nor by anie lawfull humane con≈øtitutions.
36 That the gouernement of the church of England, by lord archbi≈øhops and bi≈øhops, is not a church gouernement ≈øet downe in the worde, or which can be defended to be Gods ordinance.
37 That the gouernement of lord archbi≈øhops and bi≈øhops is vnlawefull, notwith≈øtanding it bee mainteined, and in force by humane lawes and ordinances.
38 That the humane lawes mainteining them, are wicked, and vngodly, and to be abrogated of al chri≈øtian magi≈øtrates.
39 That to be a lord bi≈øhop then is ≈øimplie vnlawefull in it ≈øelfe, that is, in re≈øpect of the office, though the man ≈øu≈øteining the ≈øame ≈øhould not abu≈øe it as our prelates do.
40 To be a lord bi≈øhop in it ≈øelfe ≈øimplie, be≈øides the abu≈øe, con≈øi≈øteth of two mon≈øtrous parts, wherof, neither ought to be in him that profe≈ø≈øeth him≈øelfe a mini≈øter.
41 The fir≈øt is, to beare an inequall and a lordlie ≈øuperioritie ouer his brethren in the mini≈øtery, and the re≈øt of the church of God vnder his iuri≈ødiction.
42 The ≈øecond is, the ioyning of the ciuill Magi≈øtracie vnto the Mini≈øterie.

That both the≈øe partes are condemned by the
written word of God. Luke 22.25. 1. Pet. 5.1,2. Mat. 20.25. Marke 10.42. 1. Cor. 8.10. Luke 12.14. 2. Tim. 2.4. and Iohn 18.36. compared with, Matth. 10.25. Luke 16.13.

43 That the hierarchie of bi≈øhops, in their ≈øuperioritie ouer their brethren, and their ciuill offices hath beene gaine≈øaide and with≈øtoode by the vi≈øible church of God ≈øucce≈ø≈øiuelie, and without intermi≈ø≈øion for the≈øe almo≈øt 500. yeeres la≈øt pa≈øt.

44 That this cau≈øe of ouerthrowing the ≈øtate of lorde bi≈øhops, and bringing in the equalitie of Mini≈øters, is no new cau≈øe, but that which hath bin manie yeeres agoe helde and maintained, euen in the fire, by the holie martires of Chri≈øt Ie≈øus.

45 That this wicked gouernement of bi≈øhops was an e≈øpeciall point, gaine≈øaid by the ≈øeruants of God, in the time of King Henrie the eight, and Q. Marie; and in the with≈øtanding whereof they died, the holie martires of Chri≈øt Ie≈øus.
46 That none euer defended this hierarchie of bi≈øhops to be lawfull, but Papi≈øts, or ≈øuch as were infected with popi≈øh errors.
47 That we haue not expelled and bani≈øhed euerie part of poperie, as long ae we maintaine L. bi≈øhops and their ≈øeates.
48 That the offices of lord archbi≈øhops and bi≈øhops, together with other their corruptions, are condemned by the doctrine of the church of England.
49 That the doctrine of the church of England condemning the places of lord bi≈øhops, is approoued by the ≈øtatutes of this kingdome, and her Maie≈øties royall prerogatiue.

50 That to be a lord bi≈øhop, is directlie again≈øt
the ≈øtatute 13. Elizab. rightlie vnder≈øtoode, and flatlie condemned by her Maie≈øties royall priuiledge.

51 That al her Maie≈øties louing ≈øubiects, Mini≈øters e≈øpeciallie, are bound by ≈øtatute (and haue the alowance of the doctrine of the church of England publi≈øhed with her Maie≈øties prerogatiue) not to acknowledge, yea, to di≈øauow, and with≈øtand the places and callings of lord bi≈øhops.

52 That the doctrine of the church of England in the dayes of King Henrie the eight was the doctrine which the ble≈ø≈øed martires of Chri≈øt Ie≈øus M. Tindall M. D. Barnes, and M. Fryth taught them and deliuered vnto vs.

53 That this doctrine of theirs is now to be accouÃÑted the doctrine of the church of Englande, in as much as (being the doctrine of Chri≈øt & his Apo≈øtles) it is publi≈øhed in print by Ma≈øter Fox, and that by her Maie≈øtiies priuiledge.
54 That this their doctrine is mainteined by ≈øtatute, vnder the name of the doctrine of the faith and ≈øacraments.

55 That the doctrine which according to the word is publi≈øhed by Mai≈øter Fox in the booke of Martyres, ≈øeeing it is, cum priuilegio, is al≈øo to bee accompted the doctrine of faith and ≈øacramentes in the church of England, and ≈øo is approoued by ≈øtatute.
56 That vpon the≈øe former groundes wee may ≈øafely holde the≈øe conclu≈øions following, and are thereby allowed by ≈øtatute, and her Maie≈øties prerogatiue.

57 That by the doctrine of the church of England, it is not po≈ø≈øible, that naturally there can be
anie good lord bi≈øhop, Ma≈øter Tindalls practi≈øe for prelates. pag. 374.
58 That by the doctrine of the church of England, a bi≈øhoprike is a ≈øuperfluous honour, and a lewd libertie, ibid.
59 That by the doctrine of the church of England, our bi≈øhops are none of the Lordes annoynting, but ≈øeruants of the bea≈øt.
60 That by the doctrine of the church of England, our lord bi≈øhops are none of Chri≈øts bi≈øhops, but the Mini≈øters of Antichri≈øt.
61 That by the doctrine of the church of Englande, our bi≈øhops and their gouernement are no part of Chri≈øts kingdome, but are of the kingdome of this world.
62 That by the doctrine of the church of England, lord bi≈øhops are a part of that body wherof Antichri≈øt is the head.
63 That by the doctrine of the church of England, the places of archbi≈øhops and bi≈øhops are the ≈øeates of Antichri≈øt.
64 That by the doctrine of the church of England, a bi≈øhop can haue no other lawfull authoritie, but onelie to preach the word.
65 That by the doctrine of the church of England, the de≈øire of a bi≈øhopricke, or anie other honor in a mini≈øter, is a note of a fal≈øe Prophet.
66 That according to the doctrine of the churche of Englande, all our bi≈øhops and their chapleines are fal≈øe prophets.
67 That the doctrine of the church of England concerning the ciuill offices of our Prelates, is, That all ciuil rule and dominion is by the word of God flatlie forbidden vnto the Cleargie.
68 That according to the doctrine of the churche of England, the mini≈øterie and the magi≈øtracie cannot by the ordinance of God bee both in one per≈øon.
69 That by the doctrine of the church of England, the ioyning together of the mini≈øterie in one per≈øon, doeth put euerie kingdome out of order.
70 That for a lord bi≈øhoppe to bee of the priuie coun≈øell in a kingdome, according to the doctrine of the church of England, is as profitable vnto the Realme, as the woolfe is to the lambes.
71 That bi≈øhoppes ought to haue no pri≈øons wherein to puni≈øh tran≈øgre≈ø≈øors.
Marke this (good Reader)72 That according to the church of Englande, all Mini≈øters be of equall authoritie.

73 That according to the doctrine of the churche of England, tho≈øe Doctors (who are dayly alleadged by our bi≈øhops in the defence of their ≈øuperioritie ouer their brethren) to wit, Cyprian, Ierom, Augu≈øtine, Chry≈øo≈øtome knewe of no authoritie that one bi≈øhop ≈øhoulde haue aboue another, neither thought, or once dreamed, that euer anie ≈øuch thing ≈øhould be.

74 That according to the doctrine of the churche of England, a bi≈øhoppe and an elder, or a mini≈øter, note out in the word of God the one and the ≈øelfe ≈øame per≈øon and church-officer, the contrary whereof is popery.
75 That by the doctrine of the church of England, it is popery to tran≈ølate the worde Presbyteros into Prie≈øt, and ≈øo to call the mini≈øters of the Go≈øpell Prie≈øts.

76 That according to the doctrine of the churche of Englande, D. Bancroft in his Sermon at
Paules the 28. of Ianuary 1588. mainteined a popi≈øh errour, in auouching, that in the dayes of Cyprian there was a difference betwene a bi≈øhop and a prie≈øt or mini≈øter.
77 That according to the doctrine of the churche of England, Iohn Cant. is a mainteiner of a popi≈øh errour, in terming the mini≈øters of the Go≈øpel by the name of prie≈øts.
78 That according to the doctrine of the churche of England, our prelates haue no authoritie to make mini≈øters, or to proceede to anie eccle≈øia≈øticall cen≈øure.
79 That by the doctrine of the church of Englande, to haue a bi≈øhops licence to preach, is the very marke of the bea≈øt Antichri≈øt.

80 That by the doctrine of the church of England, the godly mini≈øters ought to ordeine tho≈øe that would enter into that function, without anie leaue of the Prelats, & not ≈øo much as once to ≈øuffer them to take anie approbation of the Prelats.

81 That according to the doctrine of the churche of England, there ought to be no other maner of eccle≈øia≈øticall cen≈øure, but that which is noted, Matth. 18.15,17. which is, to proceede from a priuat admonition to one or two witne≈ø≈øes, & thence to the church, that is, not to one, but vnto the gouernours of the church, together with the whole congregation.
82 That according to the doctrine of our churche, the citations, proce≈ø≈øes, excommunications, &c. of the Prelates, are neyther to be obeyed nor regarded.

83 That according vnto the doctrine of the church of England, men ought not to appeare in
their courtes, ≈øeeing their proceedings are ≈øo directly again≈øt the trueth, as now they are manife≈øted to be, ≈øeeing the doctrine of the church warranteth them no ≈øuch calling.
84 That according to the doctrine of the churche of England, that a man being excommunicated by them, ought not to ≈øeeke any ab≈øolution at their hands.
85 That according vnto the doctrine of the church of Englande, euery mini≈øter is bounde to preach the Go≈øpell, notwith≈øtanding the inhibition of the bi≈øhops.
86 That according vnto the doctrine of the church of England, a man being once made a mini≈øter, is not to be kept backe from preaching, by the inhibition of any creature.

87 That according vnto the doctrine of our church, our prelates notably profane the cen≈øure of the church, by ≈øending them out again≈øt tho≈øe, who are not offendours again≈øt God, for money matters, and other trifles, &c.

88 That according vnto the doctrine of the church of England, it is great tyrannie in them, to ≈øummon and cite poore men, as they doe, to come before them, for hearing the word, or ≈øpeaking again≈øt their hierarchie.

89 That it is tyrannie by the doctrine of the church of England, and the badge of Antichri≈øts di≈øciples, for our prelates to breake vp into mens con≈øciences, to compell them by othes, to te≈øtifie again≈øt them≈øelues.
90 That by the doctrine of the church of England, our prelates learned this abomination of Pilate Matth. 26.93.
91 That according vnto the doctrine of the church of England, none ought to be in the mini≈øterie, but ≈øuch as are able to preach.
92 That according vnto the doctrine of the church of England, Nonre≈øidents, and pluralities of benefices, are mo≈øt intollerable in the ≈øight of God and man.
93 That all true ≈øubiects haue better warrant to denie the ≈øuperioritie of bi≈øhoppes, then the bi≈øhops haue to impo≈øe them≈øelues vpoÃÑ the church.

94 That her Maie≈øties true ≈øubiects in oppugning the ≈øtate of L. bi≈øhops haue the warrant of the word of God, the warrant of our laws and ≈øtatutes, the doctrine of the church of England, the con≈øent of the church of God for the ≈øpace of aboue 400. yeeres, and her Maie≈øties priuiledge.

95 That the bi≈øhops haue nothing for their defence, but the corruption receiued into our church contrary vnto the word, coÃÑtrary vnto our ≈øtatutes, contrary vnto her Maie≈øties priuiledge, contrarie vnto the doctrine of our church.

96 That our bi≈øhoppes in this controuer≈øie for their hierarchie, haue not me, poore man, for their onelie aduer≈øarie, but our ≈øauiour Chri≈øt, his Apo≈øtles, and holy Martires, our lawes and ≈øtatutes, her Maie≈øties priuiledges, and the doctrine of our church hath long agoe condemned them for traitors vnto God, vnto his word, his church, and vnto our lawes and priuiledges.

97 That Mai≈øter Thomas Cartwright, together with all tho≈øe learned men, and my ≈øelfe al≈øo that haue written again≈øt the ≈øtate of the Clargy, could do no le≈ø≈øe then we haue done, except wee woulde betray the trueth of God, the lawes of this lande,
and the doctrine of our church.

98 That our magi≈øtrates in mainteining both the doctrine of our church, and al≈øo the hierarchie of our bi≈øhops, mainteine twoo contrarie factions vnder their gouernement, which their wi≈øedomes knowe to be dangerous.
99 That this faction is likely to continue vntill eyther of the parties giue ouer.

100 That tho≈øe who defend the doctrine of our church in oppugning of our bi≈øhops, neyther can nor wil giue ouer the cau≈øe, in as much as it is confirmed by the word profe≈ø≈øed in our church allowed by our ≈øtatutes, and mainteined by her Maie≈øties priuiledge.
101 That the bi≈øhops will not giue ouer, in any likelihoode to die for it, as long as the ≈øtate will mainteine them.
102 That the continuance of the≈øe contrarie factions, is likely in a while to become very daungerous vnto our ≈øtate, as their wi≈øedomes, who are magi≈øtrates doe well know and perceiue.

103 That their wi≈øedomes then are bounde, euen for the quieting of our outward ≈øtate, to putte downe eyther the doctrine of our Church, or the corruption, viz. our bi≈øhoppes, and their proceedings.

104 That they cannot, without the endaungering of them≈øelues, vnder the wrath of God, and the odious and mo≈øt mon≈øtrous ≈øinne of ineuitable Apo≈øtacie from the trueth, put downe, and aboli≈øh the doctrine of our church.

105 That they can not any longer mainteine the corruptions of our church, namely, archbi≈øhops and bi≈øhops, without the ≈øhamefull contradiction
of our doctrine, and the di≈øcontentednes of their ≈øubiects.

106 That all Mini≈øters are bound by ≈øub≈øcription, by vertue of the ≈øtatute that requireth their ≈øub≈øcription vnto the doctrine of faith and ≈øacraments in the church of Englande, to di≈øauowe the hierarchie of bi≈øhops.
107 That it were well, that all the≈øe mini≈øters who are vrged to ≈øub≈øcribe would require a re≈øolution in this poynt, before they yeelde their ≈øub≈øcription.

108 That Doctour Bancroft in affirming her Maie≈øtie to be a pettie pope in his Sermon preached at Paules the ninth of Februarie 1588. preached trea≈øon again≈øt her Maie≈øties royall crowne and dignitie.Pag. 68. lin. 19
109 That the ≈øayde Bancroft is a traytor, in affirming, her Maie≈øtie to v≈øurpe that authoritie within her dominions, in cau≈øes eccle≈øia≈øticall which the pope v≈øurped in times pa≈øt.
110 That our bi≈øhoppes in ≈øuffering the ≈øayde Sermon to be publi≈øhed in print, conteining the former points of trea≈øon, are acce≈ø≈øary vnto Bancrofts trea≈øon.
That our prelates. Heere the father lefte his writings vnperfite, and thus perfitely beginnes the ≈øonne.

div.head: Martin Iuniors Epilogue. To the wor≈øhipfull his very good neame, Mai≈øter Iohn Canturburie.
div.p: AFter my harty commendations vnto your VVorshippe, (good nunckle Canturbury) tru≈øting, that you, vvith the re≈øt of the Cater-caps are as neere your ouerthrovve, as Jyour poore nephevv am from vvishing the pro≈øperitie of your Antichri≈øtian callings. The cau≈øe of my vvriting vnto you at this in≈øtant, is, to let you vnderstand, fir≈øt, that I vvas ≈øomevvhat merry at the making heereof, being indeed ≈øory, together vvith others of my brethren, that vvee cannot heare from our good father, Maister Martin Marprelate, that good & learned di≈øcour≈øing brother of yours, but e≈øpecially grieued, that vve ≈øee not the vtter ≈øubuer≈øion of that vnhappy and pe≈øtilent gouernement of L. Bishops, at the helme vvhereof ye ≈øitte like a Pilate, or a Caiphas rather. Moreouer, I do you to vveete, that you shal receiue by this bearer, certaine vnperfect vvritings of my fathers, praying your prelacie, if you can ≈øend mee, or any of my brethren any vvord of him, that you vvould returne vs an an≈øvvere vvith ≈øpeede.

MAny flim flam tales goe abroad of him, but of certaintie nothing can be heard, in as much as he keepeth him ≈øelfe ≈øecrete from all his ≈øonnes. Some thinke, that hee is euen nowe employed in your bu≈øine≈ø≈øe; and I thinke ≈øo too, my rea≈øon is, quoth Robert Some, becau≈øe it was for your ≈øakes and good, that hee fir≈øt fell a ≈øtudying the Arte of Pi≈øtle making: Others giue out, that in the ≈øeruice of his countrey, and her Maie≈øties, he died, or was in great danger at the Groine. And the others (ka mine vncka Bridges) haue ≈øeene motiues inducing them to be of this minde: Some there are al≈øo, who feare that you haue him in your handes. How≈øoeuer it be ≈øomewhat is not well, that hee is ≈øilent all this while. We his ≈øonnes mu≈øt needes be di≈øquieted, ≈øeeing wee can neither knowe where our father is, nor yet heare from him. If we could but heere by ≈øome Pi≈øtle, though it were but of 20. ≈øheetes of paper, that he is well, we would not then be ≈øo inqui≈øitiue of him. But now that he hath bin ≈øo long time tongue-tied the≈øe foure or fiue moneths, wee mu≈øt needes enquire of the matter. Speake then, good nuncles, haue you clo≈øly murthered the gentlman in ≈øome of your pri≈øons? haue you ≈øtrangled him? haue you giuen him an Italian figge? or, what haue you done vnto him? haue you choaked him with a fat prebend or two? What? I trowe my father wil ≈øwallow downe no ≈øuch pilles. And he doe, I can tell he will ≈øoone purge away al the con≈øcience hee hath, and prooue a mad hinde ere he die. But tell me, I pray you, what you meane to doe vnto him if you haue him in holde? Do you meane to haue the keeping of him, lea≈øt he ≈øhould not be otherwi≈øe well looked vnto? whie what need
tat? I am ≈øure he hath 500. ≈øonnes in the lande, of good credit and abilitie, with whome hee might haue other gates welcome, then with any Catercap o them all. And I pray you, nunckles, neuer trouble your ≈øelues with the keeping of him, I tru≈øt he ≈øhal do well, though he neuer come neere any of you all. And I thinke in rea≈øon it were more meete his ≈øonnes, then his brethren ≈øhoulde bee charged with him; if it ≈øo came to pa≈ø≈øe, that hee were forced to leane vnto others. This I knowe full well, that my father woulde bee ≈øory from his heart, to put you to any ≈øuch co≈øt, as you intend to bee at with him. A meaner hou≈øe, and of le≈ø≈øe ≈øtrength then the Tower, the Fleete, Newgate, or the Gate-hou≈øe is, woulde ≈øerue him well enough: he is not of that ambitious vaine, that many of his brethren the bi≈øhops are, in ≈øeeking for more co≈øtly hou≈øes then euer his father built for him. And therefore, good ≈øweete neames nowe, if you haue him, let him bee di≈øpatched out of your hands, with hone≈øty and credit. My father is of a kingly nature I perceiue by him, hee woulde doe good vnto you, but he would not be recompenced for it againe. He will none of your courte≈øies vnle≈ø≈øe it be for your owne ≈øakes, that you will giue ouer your bi≈øhopdomes, that is the greate≈øt benefite he accounts of from you, other recompence he ≈øeekes none.

If you demaund of mee, where I founde this, the trueth is, it was taken vp (together with certaine other papers) be≈øides a bu≈øh, where it had dropped from ≈øome body pa≈ø≈øing by that way. I hope my fathers wor≈øhip will not bee oftended with me, for publi≈øhing of it, being not ≈øo perfit as que≈øtionle≈ø≈øe
he would haue had it. Hee, and you, can not but commend my good dealing, in ≈øetting it out; for I cho≈øe rather to leaue the ≈øentences vnperfite then to adde any thing more then I found legible. The Arithmeticall nombers in the end of his preamble ≈øhew, that when he had written ≈øo farre, he had ≈øomething more in his head then all men doe conceiue, which made him leaue in the midde≈øt of a period. I my ≈øelfe doe perceiue ≈øome tantologies in the coÃÑclu≈øions as being the fir≈øt draught, but I would not pre≈øume to mend them, that I referre to him≈øelfe, if he be yet liuing, if dead, yet po≈øterities may haue his after-birth to be altogether his owne. And let them take this as his cygncam cantionem, viz. his farewell to booke-making. But that would I be ≈øorie of. For who can bee able to prooue the poynts which he hath ≈øet downe here, concerning the doctrine of our church, mainterned by ≈øtatur, & her Maie≈øties priuiledge, ≈øo ≈øoundly, and ≈øo worthily, as he him≈øelfe would performe it. A thirtie or fortie of the fir≈øt Conclu≈øions are alreadie ≈øhewed in, Hai any work for the Cooper, and therefore they neede no further proofe then the reading ouer that woorthie Treati≈øe, whence they ≈øeeme to haue beene collected. The re≈øt I hope ≈øhall be ≈øhewed in More worke for the Cooper.

And vather, if you can proue the≈øe thinges out of the doctrine of our church, then certainelie you de≈øerue to be chronicled for euer. Then Iohn Canturbury, come downe with thy poperie, ka M. Martin Iunior: for now art thou ≈øet out in thy colors, to be an aduer≈øary, not onely of Chri≈øt and his Apo≈øtles, which all men might know, but euen
al≈øo an vtter enemie vnto the doctrine of the church of England ≈øowed heere by the holy Martires, and ≈øealed with their blood, yea, allowed by ≈øtatute, and publi≈øhed with her Maie≈øties royall priuiledge, which is a point that the mo≈øt haue not con≈øidered of. And who is hee now that dares per≈øwade Martin to giue ouer his cour≈øe, vnle≈ø≈øe the ≈øame al≈øo will ≈øhewe him≈øelfe an enemie to the doctrine of the church of England. For Martin in his writings, is not ≈øo much an ennemie vnto the bi≈øhoppes, as a defender of the doctrine of our Churche. And therefore you Puritanes, that mi≈ølike of him, take heede that you bee not founde amonge≈øt po≈øterities, to bee the betrayers of this doctrine (for your ea≈øe and quietne≈ø≈øe ≈øake) which you are bound to deliuer vnto your children, without corruption or mangling, though it co≈øt you your liues a thou≈øande times‚ñ™ For to tell you the trueth, if you do but read ouer the writings of M. Tindall, M. Frith, M. Barnes, M. Hooper, M. Knox, M. Lambert, &c. which were the fir≈øt planters of the Go≈øpell amonge≈øt vs, you ≈øhall find your ≈øelues in faithfulnes, courage and zeale, yea, euen the be≈øt of you farre behind them; which I ≈øpeake not but to your great ≈øhame, with a de≈øire of your amendement. And therefore I tell you true, I thinke it a great ble≈ø≈øing of God that hath rai≈øed vppe this Martin, whome you can hardelie brooke, to holde tackling with the bi≈øhops, that you may haue ≈øome time of breathing, or rather a time to gather courage and zeale, ioyned with knowledge, to ≈øet vpon the≈øe enemies of the doctrine of our church, euen the doctrine of God, I meane maintained in our church. For that as hitherto
ye haue done, you be ≈øo loth (for the di≈øturbing of our ≈øtate for≈øooth, and the offending of hir Maie≈øtie) not onely to ≈øpeake again≈øt, but euen vtterlie to reiect this hierarchie of our bi≈øhops, euen to haue no more to doe with it, then with the ≈øeate of the bea≈øt, you ≈øhall declare vnto our children, that God rai≈øed vppe but a companie of whiteliuered ≈øouldiours, to teach the Go≈øpell in ≈øinceritie vnder her Maie≈øtie, and take heede le≈øt our forenamed fathers ri≈øe vppe in iudgement again≈øt you. As for her Maie≈øtie, or the ≈øtate, I think ≈øhee hath little cau≈øe to thanke you for your wi≈øedome, in ≈øeeking the quietne≈ø≈øe of this common-wealth, by-winking at the ≈øinne of the pompous mini≈øterie. And me thinkes you are bounde vnto her, and her people, to make ≈øo much at the lea≈øt knowen, as ≈øhee mainteineth publikelie in bookes, by her ≈øtatutes and priuiledges, to be the doctrine of this our church vnder her gouernement. Therefore, looke vnto the≈øe thinges, for certainelie, if euer the Lorde ≈øhall make the proceedings of our wicked bi≈øhoppes knowen vnto her Maie≈øtie, to bee ≈øo contrarie to worde of God, the profe≈ø≈øion of holie Martyres, and the doctrine of our church mainteined, both by our ≈øtatutes, and priuiledges, as in the≈øe The≈øes they are ≈øette downe, a≈ø≈øure your ≈øelfe, that ≈øhe will then enquire, whether ≈øhe had not any faithfull preachers in her kingdome, that would ≈øtand to the defence of the trueth, vntill ≈øhee ≈øawe further into it.

As for the bi≈øhops, they may herein ≈øee, to their woe, what wicked caytiffes they are, in maintaining them≈øelues & their thrice cur≈ø≈øed popedome,
again≈øt ≈øuch cleare light. But the bea≈øtes, I feare, were borne to no other end, then to be the Lords ≈øcourge, to cha≈øtice his church, and then to bee burnt in hell. And out vppon them, they are as vnlike Chri≈øt, his Apo≈øtles, and holy Martyres, which were the planters of our Churche, as the wretches are like vnto them≈øelues. A man would haue thought, if they had not beene de≈øperate in their wickedne≈ø≈øe, that by the warning which Martin gaue them, they woulde haue beene re≈øtrained from their villanie in ≈øome ≈øort. But, as though their very rea≈øon had bene cleane gone, the more they are threatned to haue their proceedings di≈øplayed, the more wicked doe they manife≈øt them≈øelues. As if they woulde declare vnto the worlde, that they will not bee made knowen vnto po≈øteritie, but vppon the condition, that they may bee the mo≈øt wicked, that euer were in the church of God. They will be ≈øo many Iuda≈øes, ≈øo many Diotrephe≈øes, ≈øo many Simon Magu≈øes, as nowe they are wicked bi≈øhoppes of Englande, or el≈øe they thinke not them≈øelues well dealte with. Wherefore, reuerend father, if you bee as yet on your feete, and haue e≈øcaped out of the danger of gunne ≈øhotte, beginne againe to play the man. Feare none of the≈øe bea≈øtes, the≈øe pur≈øuvants, the≈øe Mar-Martins, the≈øe ≈øtage-players, the≈øe prelates, the≈øe popes, the≈øe diuels, and al they can do. Quit your ≈øelfe but as like a man as you haue doone in Hai any worke, and I doubt not but you will make the≈øe rogi≈øh prie≈øts lie in the kenell. The reporte abroad goeth, that you are drawen drie, and can ≈øay no more. They are fooles that ≈øo thinke, I ≈øay,
Let the≈øe Conclu≈øions bee iudge, whereby I tell you true, I hope you ≈øhall be able to emprie euerie bi≈øhopricke in Englande, if waight of tructh can doe it. There bee that affirme, the rimers and ≈øtage-players, to haue cleane putte you out of countenaunce, that you dare not againe ≈øhew your face. Alas poore haglers, their fathers are too yoong to outface the lea≈øt of your ≈øonnes. And I doe thinke, that, lay a≈øide their tyrannie, all the bi≈øhops of Englande are too weake to deale with a ≈øcarre-crowe, that hath but the name of reuerend Martin written vppon it. And therefore, I per≈øwade my ≈øelfe, that they their ≈øelues are thorowlie ≈øo per≈øwaded, ka my nuncka Bridges, that you contemne ≈øuch kenell rakers, and ≈øcullions, as to their ≈øhame, in the time of your ≈øilence haue ≈øolde them ≈øelues for pence a peece, to be derided of come who ≈øo will, to ≈øee a companie of di≈øgui≈øed a≈ø≈øes.

Concerning Mar-martin, if he be a Londoner, or an vniuer≈øitie man, tenne to one but you ≈øhall ≈øee him, one of the≈øe odde dayes, carted out of the towne for his hone≈øtie of life. Why that time of his ≈øheweth, that hee had no other bringing vppe, then in a brothel-hou≈øe. And heerein I woulde craue pardon of the vniuer≈øities, and the famous citie of London, if I ≈øhoulde bee thought to giue out, that ≈øuch a ribaulder as this is, were there maintained. To ≈øpeake what I doe thinke of the youth, I can not bee induced to thinke, that hee hath had his bringing vp at any other trade, then in carryeng long Meg of We≈øtmin≈øters hand-ba≈øket, and in attending vppon ≈øome other of his auntes, at her appointment while ≈øhee liued. After
her death, it may be he hath beene promoted vnto the ≈øeruice of ≈øome laundre≈ø≈øe in a bi≈øhoppes hou≈øe, where, in hope to bee preferred by his good lordes, he hath vndertaken to mar-rimes, in publi≈øhing bawdery, and filthine≈ø≈øe, for the defence of the≈øe hone≈øt bi≈øhops.

The ≈øtage-players, poore ≈øeelie hunger-≈øtarued wretches, they haue not ≈øo much as an hone≈øt calling to liue in the common-wealth: And they, poore varlets, are ≈øo ba≈øe minded, as at the plea≈øure of the verye≈øt rogue in England, for one poore pennie, they will be glad on open ≈øtage to play the ignominious fooles, for an houre or two together. And therfore, poore rogues, they are not ≈øo much to be blamed, if being ≈øtage-players, that is, plaine rogues (≈øaue onely for their liueries) they in the action of dealing again≈øt Mai≈øter Martin, haue gotten them many thou≈øande eie-witne≈ø≈øes, of their wittele≈ø≈øe and pittifull conceites. And in deede they are marueilous fitte vpholders of Lambehith palace, and the crowne of Canturburie. And therefore, menne ≈øhoulde not thinke of all other things, that they ≈øhould any wayes make Mai≈øter Martin, or his ≈øonnes to alter their cour≈øe. And heereof, good Mai≈øter Canturburie, a≈ø≈øure your ≈øelfe. Well, to growe to a point with you, if you haue any of your ≈øide, eyther in the Vniuer≈øities, or in your cathedrall Churches, or any where within the compa≈ø≈øe of all the bi≈øhopdomes you haue, that dare write, or di≈øpute again≈øt anie of the≈øe pointes ≈øette downe by my father, heere I do by the≈øe my writinges, ca≈øt you downe the Gloue, in my fathers name, and the names of the re≈øt
of his ≈øonnes. If my father be gone, and none el≈øe of my brethren will vpholde the controuer≈øie again≈øt you, I my ≈øelfe will doe it. And take my challenge if you dare. By writing you may do it, qand be ≈øure to be an≈øwered. By di≈øputations, if you will appoint the place, with promi≈øe, that you will not deale vi & armis, you ≈øhall be taken al≈øo by me, if I thinke I may tru≈øt you. Otherwi≈øe, the Puritanes will, I doubt not, maintaine the chalenge again≈øt you.

But heere by the way, Iohn Canturbury, take an odde aduice of your poore nephew, and that is this. Fir≈øt, in regard of your ≈øelfe, play not the tyrant as you doe, in Gods Church; if you goe on forward in this cour≈øe, the ende will bee a wofull reckoning. Thou ha≈øt beene rai≈øed vp out of the du≈øt, and euen from the very dounghill, to bee pre≈øident of her Maie≈øties coun≈øell, being of thy ≈øelfe, a man altogether vnmeet for any ≈øuch preheminence, as neyther endued with any excellent naturall witte, nor yet with any great portion of learning. The Lorde hath pa≈ø≈øed by many thou≈øands in this land farre meeter for the place then is poore Iohn Whitgift. Well then, what if thou, hauing receiued ≈øo great ble≈ø≈øings at the Lordes hand (beeing of all others in no compari≈øon anye thing neere the fitte≈øt for it, or the likelie≈øt to obraine it) ≈øhalt now ≈øhew thy ≈øelfe vngratefull vnto thy mercifull Lorde God, or become a cruell per≈øecutour, and a tyrant in his church, a cruell oppre≈ø≈øour of his children, ≈øhall not all that thou ha≈øt receiued, be tourned vnto a cur≈ø≈øe vnto thee, euen into thine owne bo≈øome? Yea verely. For
the Lorde in one day is able to bring more ≈øhame vpon thee, and that in this life, then he hath heaped ble≈ø≈øings vpon thee now for the ≈øpace of thirtie yeeres and vpward. But when I doe con≈øider thy preheminence and promotion, I do ≈øen≈øiblie acknowledge it to be ioyned with a rare cur≈ø≈øe of God, euen ≈øuch a cur≈ø≈øe as very fewe (I will not ≈øay none) in Gods Church doe ≈øu≈øtaine. And that is thy wicked and Antichri≈øtian Prelacie. The con≈øideration of which popedome of thine maketh me thinke, that thy other place in the ciuill magi≈øtracie, being in it ≈øelfe a godly and a lawfull calling, is ≈øo become infectious, that it will be thy bane, both in this life, and in the life to come. And I am almo≈øt fully per≈øwaded, that, that archbi≈øhopricke of thine, together with thy practi≈øes therein, ≈øhew verely, that the Lorde hath no part nor portion in that mi≈øerabble, and de≈øperat caytiffe wicked Iohn Whitgift, the Pope of Lambehith. Leaue therefore both thy popedome, and thy vngodly proceedings, or looke for a fearefull ende.

My ≈øecond and la≈øt adui≈øe is this in a word. Suffer no more of the≈øe haggling and profane pamphlets to be publi≈øhed again≈øt Martin, and in defence of thy hierarchie. Otherwi≈øe thou ≈øhalt but commend thy follie and ignorance vnto the world to be notorious. Mar-martin, Leonard Wright, Fregneuile, Dick Bancroft, Tom Blan. o Bedford, Kemp, Vnderhil, ≈øerue thee for no other v≈øe, but to worke thy ruine, and to bewray their owne ≈øhame, & mi≈øerable ignorance. Thus far of the≈øe matters.

And mee thinkes you ≈øee, nunckle Canturburie, that though I bee but young, yet I beginne
prettily well to followe my fathers ≈øteppes; for I promi≈øe you, I am deceiued, vnle≈ø≈øe I haue a prety ≈ømattering gift in this Pi≈øtle-making, and I feare in a while I ≈øhall take a pride in it. I pray you, if you can, now I haue ≈øhewed you my minde, that you woulde be a meanes, that my vather, or my brethren be not offended with me for my pre≈øuming this of mine owne head. I did all of a good meaning, to ≈øaue my fathers papers: and it would haue pitied your heart to ≈øee, how the poore papers were raine and weather-beaten, euen truely in ≈øuch a ≈øort, as they coulde ≈øcant bee read to bee printed. There was neuer a drie threede in them. The≈øe ≈øea-iourneys are pittifull I perceiue. One thing me thinkes my father ≈øhould like in me, and that is, my mode≈øtie, for I haue not pre≈øumed, to publi≈øhe mine in as large a print or volume as my father doth his. Nay, I thinke it well, if I can drible out a Pi≈øtle in octauo nowe and then. Farewell, good nuncle, and pay this bearer for the cariage. Iuly 22. 1589. With as great ≈øpeede as I might.
